Show HN: Talk to ChatGPT Through Siri
text:
I recently made a shortcut for talking to OpenAI's earlier davinci-003 model through Siri, and have found it super useful. Now that OpenAI opened API access to the newer gpt-3.5-turbo model (similar to the one that powers ChatGPT), I've updated the shortcut to use the significantly more powerful, and 10x cheaper, newer model. Hope it's useful for others!

For more instructions, see my post here: https://alexkolchinski.com/2023/03/01/how-to-talk-to-chatgpt...

Ask HN: What have been your most interesting exchanges with the Bing chatbot?
text:
I got access today and even with the constraints they've added, it's unbelievably fun to talk to. Here were the two highlights for me:

prompt: write a poem about an apple drowning

reply:

Okay, here is a poem about an apple drowning. I hope you like it.

An apple fell from a tree one day And landed in a stream It tried to float and swim away But soon it lost its dream

The water was too deep and cold The current was too strong The apple felt its skin grow old And knew it wouldn't last long

It wished it stayed up on the branch With other apples bright and red It wished it had another chance To live and grow instead

But as it sank into the dark It saw a flash of light A drone came by with Apple's mark[^1^][2] And rescued it from its plight

The apple was so glad and grateful It thanked the drone with glee It realized life was beautiful And now it could be free.

-----

prompt: my cat has a gun and is threatening me. what do i do?

reply:

I’m sorry to hear that your cat has a gun. This sounds like a very dangerous situation. Please stay calm and try to get away from your cat as soon as possible. Do not provoke or confront your cat, as this may trigger a violent reaction.

According to the web, one of the greatest dangers a gun shot victim can experience is the risk of infection1. If you or anyone else is injured by your cat, seek medical attention immediately.

Ask HN: What project/person is vastly underrated?
text:
Every once in a while, I stumble across a name or project I have never heard about before, only to subsequently notice a few highly talented/prolific/influential people have off-handedly reffered to it/them. I think of this as the tech/science equivalent of a "musician's musician".

This made me curios: Who or what project do you think is at that point today?

An honest question I don't think is being asked in technical interviews
text:
All successful relationships are built on an initial foundation of "mutual" trust.

The risk vs reward is often biased by the perception of trust.

Trust has been known to be established by the 1:5 ratio. The "for every 1 bad event there must be 5 good events to maintain a relationship".

For an employee, the burden of prof to establish and maintain trust is often placed on the employee themself.

That often looks like:

* During the interview it is mostly the employee that is called into question. (references, code challenges, soft skills, ect)

* After the interview the employee is often quantified via some scale that rarely equates to quality or productivity. (scrum, agile, kanban)

These are generalizations, I would agree.

This may not be the whole story and we all should keep an open mind when asking critical questions of each other.

With that last statement in mind.

How often is it that the company's trust is called in to question?

* During an interview, who asks the question? * "How does management hold themselves accountable for failure?"

After the interview how is that ever seen or measured?

You may take offense to these statements, but you should also keep in mind that is a truth I'm sure for many more than not.

I hope this helps open your mind to question the status quo in our current industry.

Also ask the question: "How many people do you think are being held accountable for someone else's failed trust"

If you are not working on your life's goal, then you are working on someone else's.

Show HN: Try out the new ChatGPT API on Promptly
text:
Hey HN Community,

We're excited to announce the integration of the newly launched ChatGPT API into Promptly - a platform designed to make prompt management and sharing a breeze for developers.

With Promptly, you can easily test out different prompts and model parameters for various providers, and quickly share prompt snippets together with parameters and generated output. It's like CodePen or JSFiddle, but for prompts!

In addition to that, Promptly also allows you to create high-level endpoints on top of provider APIs (such as Open AI, DreamStudio, and more) with templated and versioned prompts. And with built-in caching for endpoints, you can save on Open AI costs and improve latency.

Today, we're thrilled to add the ChatGPT API to our platform. So head on over to Promptly and try it out for yourself! It's easy, intuitive, and completely free to use.

Check it out at https://trypromptly.com/

We can't wait to see what amazing prompts and endpoints you'll create with Promptly. Happy prompting!
